title: Psalm 23 Quiz
description: Test your knowledge of Psalm 23 — The Lord is My Shepherd — covering all 6 verses, David's shepherd background, key Hebrew words, and why this psalm brings comfort.

questions.question: What is the opening declaration of Psalm 23?
options: The LORD is my shepherd; I shall not want
The LORD is my rock and my fortress
The LORD is my light and my salvation
The LORD is my strength and my shield
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD is my shepherd; I shall not want
questions.explanation: Psalm 23:1 begins with the famous declaration 'The LORD is my shepherd; I shall not want.' David uses the personal pronoun 'my' — this is not an abstract theological statement but a personal relationship with God as provider and protector.

questions.question: When David says 'I shall not want' in Psalm 23:1, what does he mean?
options: God provides everything he truly needs, so he lacks nothing
He has no desires of any kind
He is wealthy and has no material needs
He does not want God's help
questions.correctAnswer: God provides everything he truly needs, so he lacks nothing
questions.explanation: 'I shall not want' expresses complete contentment in God's provision. Because the LORD is his shepherd, David lacks nothing essential. It does not mean he has no desires, but that God faithfully supplies what he needs.

questions.question: According to Psalm 23:2, where does the LORD make David lie down?
questions.explanation: Psalm 23:2 says, 'He maketh me to lie down in green pastures: he leadeth me beside the still waters.' Green pastures represent abundant provision and rest — a shepherd leads his flock to the best grazing land.

questions.question: True or False: 'Still waters' in Psalm 23:2 refers to calm, quiet waters where sheep can safely drink.
questions.explanation: Sheep are afraid of rushing water and will not drink from fast-moving streams. A good shepherd leads them to still, calm waters where they can drink safely. This pictures God leading His people to places of peace and spiritual refreshment.

questions.question: What does 'He restoreth my soul' mean in Psalm 23:3?
options: God revives and refreshes David spiritually when he is weary or wandering
God gives David a new physical body
God makes David forget his past sins
God restores David's kingdom after defeat
questions.correctAnswer: God revives and refreshes David spiritually when he is weary or wandering
questions.explanation: 'He restoreth my soul' means God brings spiritual renewal and revival. The Hebrew word 'shub' (restore) can also mean 'to bring back,' suggesting that when the sheep wanders, the shepherd retrieves and refreshes it.

questions.question: In Psalm 23:4, what does David say he will fear no evil even though he walks through?
options: The valley of the shadow of death
questions.correctAnswer: The valley of the shadow of death
questions.explanation: Psalm 23:4 reads, 'Yea, though I walk through the valley of the shadow of death, I will fear no evil: for thou art with me.' The 'valley of the shadow of death' represents the darkest, most dangerous trials of life — including death itself.

questions.question: Why does David fear no evil in the valley of the shadow of death?
options: Because he has a large army
Because the valley is not real
questions.explanation: David's courage is not based on his own strength but on God's presence: 'for thou art with me.' Notice that in verse 4, the psalm shifts from 'He' to 'thou' — David moves from talking about God to talking to God, reflecting deepening intimacy in the darkest hour.

questions.question: What two shepherd's tools does David mention in Psalm 23:4 that comfort him?
questions.explanation: 'Thy rod and thy staff they comfort me.' The rod was a short club used to fend off predators, and the staff was a long pole with a crook used to guide and rescue sheep. Together they represent God's protection and guidance.

questions.question: According to Psalm 23:5, where does God prepare a table for David?
options: In the presence of his enemies
In the temple of the LORD
In the land of milk and honey
questions.correctAnswer: In the presence of his enemies
questions.explanation: 'Thou preparest a table before me in the presence of mine enemies.' God does not merely protect David from enemies — He blesses him lavishly right in front of them. This is a picture of bold, unshakeable provision even in hostile circumstances.

questions.question: True or False: Anointing the head with oil in Psalm 23:5 was a sign of honor and blessing in ancient Israel.
questions.explanation: 'Thou anointest my head with oil' reflects the ancient Near Eastern custom of anointing an honored guest with fragrant oil. It signifies God's favor, joy, and consecration. Shepherds also applied oil to sheep's wounds for healing.

questions.question: What does David say his cup does in Psalm 23:5?
questions.explanation: 'My cup runneth over' means God's blessings are so abundant that they overflow beyond what David can contain. It is a picture of superabundant generosity — God does not merely meet needs, He exceeds them.

questions.question: According to Psalm 23:6, what two things shall follow David all the days of his life?
questions.explanation: 'Surely goodness and mercy shall follow me all the days of my life.' The Hebrew word for 'follow' (radaph) actually means 'to pursue' — God's goodness and mercy actively chase after David, not merely trailing behind.

questions.question: True or False: David wrote Psalm 23 from personal experience as a shepherd who tended his father's flocks.
questions.explanation: David was a literal shepherd before becoming king of Israel (1 Samuel 16:11, 17:34-36). He tended his father Jesse's sheep in Bethlehem and defended them against lions and bears. This firsthand experience gives Psalm 23 its vivid, authentic imagery.

questions.question: Where does David say he will dwell forever, according to Psalm 23:6?
options: In the house of the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: In the house of the LORD
questions.explanation: 'And I will dwell in the house of the LORD for ever.' The psalm that begins with God as shepherd ends with eternal fellowship with God. 'The house of the LORD' represents God's presence — David's ultimate hope is to be with God forever.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Psalm 23:4: 'Yea, though I walk through the valley of the shadow of death, I will fear no ___.'
questions.explanation: Psalm 23:4 (KJV): 'Yea, though I walk through the valley of the shadow of death, I will fear no evil: for thou art with me; thy rod and thy staff they comfort me.'
